issue.title: LedaKemLT52 cannot be run in a worker thread on macOS
issue.body:
Due to small stack size of worker threads under macOS (512kb), LEDAKEM52LT emits a BUS ERROR (access violations -Exception: EXC_BAD_ACCESS (code=1, address=0x70000292c4c8) ) when attempted to be run in a non-main (worker) thread under macOS. The first culprit is

https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/fb458165698c5850dcf08d7268a2b6c90e47e378/src/kem/ledacrypt/pqclean_ledakemlt52_leaktime/dfr_test.c#L13

where the array `gamma` seems to have 609068 bytes, more than can be stored on the stack of a single non-main thread in macOS (512kb). Allocating `gamma` on the heap still doesn't solve the problem, other violations of the same sort keep appearing (I didn't have time to go over the rest). So we should think whether we want to keep the code as is, or document that it shouldn't be run on a thread under macOS, or change it.

comment.body: WONTFIX for now.

issue.title: liboqs Compilation Error
issue.body:
Hello, I tried to compile it on Ubuntu 18.04.04, and I get the following errors:
`[9/661] Building C object src/common/CMakeFiles/common.dir/rand_nist.c.o
FAILED: src/common/CMakeFiles/common.dir/rand_nist.c.o 
/usr/bin/cc  -Iinclude -fvisibility=hidden   -Wall -Wextra -Wpedantic -Wimplicit -Wunused -Wcomment -Wchar-subscripts -Wuninitialized -Wstrict-prototypes -Wshadow -Wformat-security -Wwrite-strings -O3 -fomit-frame-pointer -march=native   -std=gnu11 -MD -MT src/common/CMakeFiles/common.dir/rand_nist.c.o -MF src/common/CMakeFiles/common.dir/rand_nist.c.o.d -o src/common/CMakeFiles/common.dir/rand_nist.c.o   -c ../src/common/rand_nist.c
../src/common/rand_nist.c:71:14: error: conflicting types for ‘OQS_randombytes_nist_kat_init’
 OQS_API void OQS_randombytes_nist_kat_init(unsigned char *entropy_input, unsigned char *personalization_string, int security_strength) {
              ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
In file included from include/oqs/oqs.h:18:0,
                 from /usr/local/include/openssl/evp.h:18,
                 from ../src/common/rand_nist.c:16:
include/oqs/rand.h:66:14: note: previous declaration of ‘OQS_randombytes_nist_kat_init’ was here
 OQS_API void OQS_randombytes_nist_kat_init(const uint8_t *entropy_input, const uint8_t *personalization_string, int security_strength);
              ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
[14/661] Building C object src/kem/bike/CMakeFiles/bike1_l1_cpa.dir/additional/decode.c.o
ninja: build stopped: subcommand failed.`
I tried to compile it a few moments ago.

_Originally posted by @Septien in https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/issues/653#issuecomment-597757006_

comment.body: Closing issue.  If you're still encountering the problem, please re-open the issue or start a new issue.

issue.title: fixing multiple defs linker errors
issue.body:
We need those flag variables to be declared `extern` in the header file `common.h`, and have them defined in `common.cpp`, otherwise we get "multiple definition error" when linking object files that each include "common.h" (that's why the liboqs-cpp wrapper is emitting a linker error in unit testing, see https://travis-ci.com/github/open-quantum-safe/liboqs-cpp/jobs/310866948). Do we want the flags to be visible in the oqs object file? That's what I assumed, and used `OQS_API` for the definitions in `common.c`.

We may also consider grouping all flags in a `struct`...

comment.body: @vsoftco Thanks very much: Looking at the changes, this is a logically correct fix to the downstream errors observed. I'm out of my depth though why Windows doesn't "like" the definitions (see AppVeyor build).

issue.title: Runtime feature detection

comment.body: Yes, it does :-( but there's a fix with PR #692 (Thanks @vsoftco !). I'd probably extend it with an (OQS_) define for RT detection so that this whole feature can be toggled on or off as not everyone needs it and we can selectively activate it as we work through the whole stack.

issue.title: Merged upstream tag 1.1.1f
issue.body: Merges upstream tag `OpenSSL_1_1_1f`. Fixes issue #161, deprecates PR #164.

comment.body:
@xvzcf @gadoofou87 : I think I understand it: the failure is due to this `cmake` instruction not working with static libs (it works like a charm with shared libs): 
```
if(DEFINED CPUFEATURES_LIBRARY)
    target_link_libraries(oqs PRIVATE ${CPUFEATURES_LIBRARY})
endif()
```

The `cpu_features` symbol is (well, should be) "localised" into liboqs and this way be available to downstream apps like openssl (again, for shared libs it works this way but not for static ones).
  
-> Does any one of you know why this is so? I checked `make VERBOSE=1` output and indeed, unlike during shared linking, no reference to `-lcpu_features` is made there. Is this a `cmake` bug?

issue.title: add define indicating cpu_feature use
issue.body: `OQS_ENABLE_CPUFEATURES` if set indicates support for CPU feature (runtime) detection. Now only activated when `.CMake/cpu_extensions.cmake` executes OK. If not activated, eliminates the need for the `cpu_features` symbols/library. Resolves build issues when building without `Optimized` CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE set.

comment.body: Could you rebase with master? And I assume the CircleCI tests are running in your account? I'll take a look at why it doesn't run here ...

issue.title: Change hybrid curve numbers to use private range as recommended in Internet-Draft
issue.body: https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-stebila-tls-hybrid-design-03 says the code points reserved for hybrid private use are `0x2F00..0x2FFF`, so we should use that range.

comment.body: We don't have hard dependencies on the currently implemented code points, so it should be ok to modify them. What about non-hybrid algorithms?

issue.title: Windows Issues
issue.body:
On my Windows 10 Enterprise VM, with with Ninja build tool and MSVC compiler. Target platform as reported by `speed_sig`: AMD64-Windows-10.0.18363.

1) Using 32-bit `cl.exe`, the build fails with the following messages:

![sike_fail](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21228961/78150570-77b17b00-7405-11ea-944b-869260ec974c.png)

For 64-bit builds:

2) `Rainbow-Vc-Cyclic` keypair generation takes 71.156 seconds, as measured by `speed_sig`. Signing takes 35.61 seconds. It once increased the runtime of `ninja run_tests` by 10 minutes, but this seems to be non-deterministic.

3) The SPHINCS and Rainbow variants seem in general to impose a big slow down on `ninja run_tests`.

4) `kat_sig` with `Falcon-512` and `Falcon-1024` results in heap corruption errors.

comment.body: I don't think we officially support win32. If that's in scope, we should at a minimum add CI tests for it (appveyor currently only target x64). Do we support/test 32-bit on linux/mac?

issue.title: CircleCI testing for Windows

comment.body: I got a response from CircleCI that they do not currently offer Windows support on their open source plans.  The response says they intend to do so in the future, but don't have a timeline.

issue.title: Change hybrid curve numbers to use private range as recommended in Internet-Draft
issue.body: https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-stebila-tls-hybrid-design-03 says the code points reserved for hybrid private use are `0x2F00..0x2FFF`, so we should use that range.

comment.body: We would leave those in the current private range; the Internet-Draft doesn't speak to PQ-only KEX methods.

issue.title: Windows Issues
issue.body:
On my Windows 10 Enterprise VM, with with Ninja build tool and MSVC compiler. Target platform as reported by `speed_sig`: AMD64-Windows-10.0.18363.

1) Using 32-bit `cl.exe`, the build fails with the following messages:

![sike_fail](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21228961/78150570-77b17b00-7405-11ea-944b-869260ec974c.png)

For 64-bit builds:

2) `Rainbow-Vc-Cyclic` keypair generation takes 71.156 seconds, as measured by `speed_sig`. Signing takes 35.61 seconds. It once increased the runtime of `ninja run_tests` by 10 minutes, but this seems to be non-deterministic.

3) The SPHINCS and Rainbow variants seem in general to impose a big slow down on `ninja run_tests`.

4) `kat_sig` with `Falcon-512` and `Falcon-1024` results in heap corruption errors.

comment.body: No, we don't support/test 32-bit on Linux or Mac.  Do any of our use cases have a need for 32-bit?
